Job
In the land named Uz, there was a man named Job. He obeyed God and always avoided doing evil things.
He had seven sons and three daughters.

He owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, one thousand oxen, and five hundred donkeys. He also had many servants. This was the man who was the richest in all the area east of the Jordan River.
Job's sons often held feasts in their houses. Whenever each one made a feast, he would invite all his brothers and sisters to come and eat together.

After each celebration, Job would summon them. He would ask Yahweh to purify them from any action they might have committed during their feasting that would make them unacceptable to him. He would get up early in the morning, kill animals, and burn them on the altar as sacrifices, one for each of his children. For Job always said, "Perhaps my children have sinned and said something evil about God in their hearts."
One day, the angels came and gathered together in front of Yahweh, and Satan came, too.
Yahweh asked Satan, "Where have you just come from?"
Satan replied, "I have come from the earth, where I been traveling back and forth to see what is happening."
Yahweh said to Satan, "Have you noticed Job, who worships me? No one else on earth honors me and lives in such a right way as he does. He always refuses to do anything evil."
Satan replied to Yahweh, "What you say is true, but Job honors you only because of what you have done for him.
You have always protected him, his family, and everything he owns. You make him succeed in whatever work he tries to do, and he has very much livestock all over his land.
But if you attacked what he owns and took it away, he would curse you in front of everyone."
Yahweh replied to Satan, "So this is what you want me to do! All right, I will permit you to take away everything that he has. But do not harm him in his own body."
Satan agreed and then left Yahweh in order to plan how he would attack Job.
One day after that, Job's sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the home of their oldest brother.
While they were doing that, a messenger arrived at Job's home and said to him, "While your oxen were plowing the fields and the donkeys were grazing nearby,

a group of men from the people group of Sheba came and attacked us. They killed all your servants who were working in the fields and took away all the oxen and donkeys! I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."

While he was still talking to Job, another messenger arrived. He said to Job, "Lightning from the sky struck and killed all the sheep and all the men who were taking care of them! I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."

While he was still talking to Job, a third messenger arrived. He said to Job, "Three groups of robbers from the region of Chaldea came and attacked us. They stole all the camels and killed all the men who were taking care of them. I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."
While he was still talking to Job, a fourth messenger arrived. He said to Job: "Your sons and daughters were feasting in the home of their oldest brother.

Suddenly a very strong wind came from the desert and struck the house. The house collapsed on your sons and daughters and killed them all! I am the only one who has escaped to come and tell you what happened."
Then Job stood up and tore his robe and shaved his head because he was very sad. Then he laid down on the ground to worship God.
He said,
"When I was born, I was wearing no clothes.
When I die, I will not take any clothes with me.
It is Yahweh who gave me everything that I possessed,
and it is Yahweh who has taken it all away.
But we must always praise Yahweh!"
So in spite of all the things that happened to Job, he did speak not like a foolish man—he did not sin by saying that what God had done was wrong.
On another day, the angels came again and gathered together in front of Yahweh; Satan also came again.
Yahweh asked Satan, "Where have you come from this time?" Satan replied, "I have come from the earth, where I have been traveling back and forth to see what is happening."
Yahweh asked Satan, "You have you noticed my servant Job, who worships me, have you not?
He continues to honor me; he is very exceptional, for he lives in a way that is more right than anyone else on the earth. He does this even though you persuaded me to attack him for no reason."
Satan replied to Yahweh, "He praises you only because you have helped him. People will give up everything they have to save their own lives.
But if you harm his body, he will surely curse you in front of everyone!"
Yahweh replied to Satan, "All right, you may do to him whatever you like, but do not cause him to die."
So Satan left, and he caused Job to suffer with very painful boils, from the top of his head to the bottom of his feet.
Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped the boils on his skin, and he sat in ashes to mourn and wail.
His wife said to him, "Are you still trying to be loyal to God? You should curse God, and then go ahead and die."

But Job replied, "You talk like people talk who do not know God. We should not only accept the good things that God does for us. We should also accept the bad things." So in spite of all these things that happened to Job, he did not offend God by saying anything against him.

Among Job's friends were Eliphaz from the town of Teman, Bildad from the land of Shuah, and Zophar from the land of Naamah. When they heard about all the terrible things that had happened to Job, they left their homes and went together to Job to mourn with him and to comfort him.

But when they saw Job from a distance, they almost did not recognize him. They wailed loudly, they tore their robes, and they threw dust into the air that settled on their heads. They did this to show how sorry they were for him.

Then they sat on the ground with Job for seven days. None of them said anything to him, because they saw that he was suffering greatly, and they did not think that anything that they could say would lessen his pain.
Finally, Job spoke, and he cursed the day that he was born.
He said,
"I wish that the day when I was born could be eradicated,
the night when I was born.
I wish that the day when I was born could have been dark.
I wish that God who is in heaven would forget about that day,
and that the sun would not have shone on it.
I wish that thick darkness would have filled that day,
and that death would have come over it like a shadow
and blotted out all light,
and caused the people then to be terrified.
I wish that the night when I was born would be erased from the calendar,
that it would never again appear as one night in any month,
and that it would not be included in any calendar.
I wish that no child would again be born on that date,
and that no one would again be happy then.
The magicians who are able to awaken the great sea monster—I want them to curse the day I was born.
I wish that the stars that shone early in the morning on that day after I was born may not shine again.
If only those stars had wished in vain for light to shine,
and that they had not shone on that day.
That was an evil day because my mother's womb was not closed;
instead, I was born, and I have now experienced all these terrible things.
I wish that I had died when I was born;
I wish I had perished when I came out from my mother's womb.
I wish that my mother had never welcomed me.
I wish that she had not nursed me at her breasts.
If I had died at the time when I was born,
I would now be asleep, resting peacefully.
I would be resting with kings who built beautiful tombs which are now in ruins,
and I would be resting with their officials who have also died.
I would be resting with princes who were wealthy,
whose palaces were filled with gold and silver.
I wish that I had been buried like a child who had died in its mother's womb
and never lived to see the light.
After wicked people die, they do not cause any more troubles;
those who are very tired now will rest.
Those who were in prison rest peacefully after they die;
they no longer have slave drivers who curse them.
Rich people and poor people are alike after they die,
and those who were slaves no longer have to obey their masters.
Why does God allow those who are suffering greatly like me to continue to remain alive?
Why does he allow them to live, those who are very miserable?
They long to die, but they do not die.
They desire to die more than people desire to find hidden treasure.
When they finally die and are buried, they are very happy.
I do not understand why God keeps alive anyone whom he keeps from being happy,
anyone whom he forces to live in misery.
I cry very much; as a result, I cannot eat;
I groan as easily as a river flows with water.
Things that I always worried might happen to me—these things have happened to me;
things that I always dreaded have come upon me.
Now I have no peace in my heart;
I have no quietness;
I cannot rest;
instead, I have only troubles."
Then Eliphaz replied to Job. He said,
"Will you please allow me to say something to you?
I am not able to remain silent any longer.
In the past, you have instructed many people,
and you have encouraged those for whom it was difficult to trust in God.
In the past, when you spoke to others who were suffering, you helped them;
they were able to rejoice again because of God.
But now, when you yourself suffer from disasters, you become discouraged.
The disasters hit you, and you are stunned.
You say that you honor God; so you should be trusting in him, for him not to let you suffer.
If you really had not sinned, you would have been confident that God would not let these disasters happen to you!
Think about this: No innocent people ever die when they are still young!
God never kills innocent people!
I have seen this happen: if farmers plant bad seeds, they do not harvest good crops;
anyone who starts trouble for others later brings trouble on himself.
These people die when God commands them to,
because he is very angry with them.
Even though wicked people may be very powerful like young lions,
God destroys them.
They will die like older lions that starve to death when there are no animals left to eat.
Their children will scatter from each other like young lions that separate from each other to find food.
I heard a message that someone came
and whispered to me.
He spoke to me at night when I was having a bad dream that disturbed me.
It caused me to be afraid and tremble;
it caused all my bones to shake.
A ghost glided past my face
and caused the hair on the back of my neck to stand straight up.
It stopped, but I could not see what it really looked like.
But I knew that there was some being in front of me,
and it said in a quiet voice,
'No human being can be more righteous than God.
No man can be better than God, who made him.
God cannot be sure that his own angels will always do what is right;
he declares that some of them have done wrong.
So he certainly cannot trust human beings whom he has made from dust and clay,
human beings, whom disaster crushes as easily as you can crush a moth!
People are sometimes in good health in the morning, but by the evening they are dead.
They are gone forever and no one even pays attention.
Their families and possessions are like tents that collapse suddenly when you pull up their stakes;
they perish suddenly without anyone ever knowing why.'"
"Job, no one will stop you from calling out for someone to help you,
but I am certain that no angel will come to you!
Foolish people die because they are resentful;
people whom others easily deceive—these people die because they envy others.
I have seen foolish people who seemed to be successful,
but suddenly they experienced disaster because I cursed their home.
Their sons are never safe;
they always lose to their opponents in court,
because there is no one to defend them.
Hungry people steal the crops that foolish people harvest;
they even steal the crops that grow among thorns,
and greedy people take away the wealth of those foolish people.
But it is not the farmland that makes bad things happen;
troubles do not grow up from the ground like plants.
People make trouble for themselves from the time that they are born;
this is as certain as the fact that sparks shoot up from a fire.
If I were suffering like you are, I would ask God for help
and tell him what I am complaining about.
He does great things, things that we cannot understand;
we cannot even count the marvelous things that he does.
He sends rain on the ground;
he makes it rain on our fields.
He defends those who are humble,
and puts those who mourn into places where they are safe.
He causes crafty people to not be able to do what they plan to do,
with the result that they achieve nothing.
The people who think they are wise—he makes their own traps catch them;
the result is that they do not succeed.
It is as though even in the daytime they were living in darkness
and were groping around trying to find the road at noontime like people do at night.
But God saves helpless people from the wicked who say evil things about them;
he saves poor people from powerful people harming them.
So poor people confidently expect that good things will happen to them;
but God stops wicked people from saying evil things.
But those whom God corrects are fortunate;
so do not despise it when God, who can do anything, disciplines you.
He wounds people, but then he puts bandages on those wounds;
he hurts people, but he also heals them.
He will rescue you many times from your troubles,
with the result that nothing evil will happen to you.
When there is little food to eat, he will not allow you to die,
and when there is a war, your enemies will not kill you.
God will protect you when people say false, evil things about you;
you will not be afraid when many things around you perish.
You will be able to laugh when that happens and when there is nothing to eat,
and you will not be afraid of wild animals.
You will not worry about having big rocks in your fields that will make plowing difficult,
and you will not worry that wild animals might attack you.
You will know that things will go well for you in your home;
when you look at your livestock, you will see that they are all there.
You will be certain that you will have many descendants,
who will be as numerous as blades of grass.
You will become very old before you die,
like sheaves of grain continue to grow until it is time to harvest and thresh them.
My friends and I have thought carefully about these things, and we know that they are true,
so pay attention to what I have said!"
Then Job spoke again to Eliphaz:
"If all my troubles and misery could be put on a scale and weighed,
they would be heavier than all the sand along the ocean shores.
That is why I spoke very rashly about the day that I was born.
It is as though Almighty God has shot me with arrows.
It is as though those arrows have poison on their tips, and that poison has gone into my spirit.
The things that God has done to me are like soldiers lined up to attack me.
Just like a wild donkey does not complain by braying when it has plenty of grass to eat,
and an ox does not complain by bellowing when it has food to eat,
I would not complain if you were really helping me.
People complain when they must eat food that has no salt
or food that is slimy and tasteless;
that is what your words are like, Eliphaz.
I do not want to eat food like that,
because it disgusts me,
and I do not like what you have said to me.
I wish that God would do for me what I have asked of him:
I wish that he would crush me and let me die.
I wish that he would reach out his hand and take away my life.
If he would do that, I would be comforted because I would know that in spite of the great pain that I have suffered,
I have always obeyed what God, the Holy One, has commanded.
But now I do not have enough strength to endure all these things.
And since I have nothing to hope for in the future,
it is difficult for me to be patient now.
I am not strong like rocks are,
and my body is not made of bronze.
So I am not able to help myself;
I am not wise enough for that.
When a man has many troubles, his friends should be kind to him,
even if he stops honoring Almighty God.
But you, my friends, are not dependable.
You are like streams in the wilderness: They spill over their banks in the spring
when the melting ice and snow make them overflow,
but when the dry season comes, there is no water flowing in those streams,
and the channels dry up.
The caravans of merchants turn off their road to search for water,
but there is no water in those streambeds,
so the merchants die in the desert.
The men in those caravans searched for some water
because they were sure that they would find some.
But they did not find any,
so they were very disappointed.
Similarly, you friends have not helped me at all!
You have seen that terrible things have happened to me,
and you are afraid that God might do similar things to you.
After I lost all my wealth, I did not ask any of you for money.
I did not plead with any of you to spend some of your money to help me.
I never asked any of you to rescue me from my enemies,
and I did not ask you to save me from those who oppressed me.
Answer me now, and then I will be quiet;
tell me what wrong things I have done!
When people speak what is true, it can be painful for the listener to hear honest words.
But what have all your arguments proven about me?
I am a man who has nothing to hope for,
but you try to correct me, and you think what I say is as useless as the wind!
You do not sympathize with me at all for the things
You will do anything to get something for yourselves! You would even play a game to see who gets an orphan as a prize!
Please look at me! I will not lie while I am talking straight to you.
Stop saying that I have sinned, and stop criticizing me unjustly!
You should realize that I have not done things that are wrong.
Do you think that I am lying?
No, I am not lying, because I know what is right to say, and what is wrong."
"People need to work hard on this earth like soldiers do;
all during the time that we are alive, we need to work as hard as any hired worker.
We are like slaves who keep wanting to be in the cool of evening,
and we are like workers who keep waiting to be paid.
God has given to me many months in which I think that it is useless to remain alive;
he has assigned to me many nights during which I feel miserable.
When I lie down at night I say, 'How long will it be until I get up?'
But the nights are long, and I toss on my bed until the dawn.
My body is covered with maggots and scabs;
pus oozes out of my open sores.
My days pass as quickly as a weaver's shuttle;
when one day ends, I never expect that things will be better the next day.
God, do not forget that my life is as short as a single breath;
I think that I will never again experience being happy.
God, you see me now,
but some day you will not see me anymore.
You will search for me, but I will be gone because I will be dead.
Like a cloud passes and disappears,
people die and descend to the place where dead people are, and they do not return;
they never return to their houses,
and the people who are still alive do not remember them anymore.
So I will not be silent;
while I am suffering, I will speak;
I will complain to God about what has happened to me
because I am very angry.
God, why do you watch closely what I am doing?
Do you think that I am a dangerous sea monster?
When I lie down at night, I say to myself, 'I will go to sleep and stop suffering;
my pain will be less while I am sleeping.'
But then you give me dreams that cause me to be afraid;
you give me visions that terrify me;
these things make me wish that someone would strangle me to death,
rather than for me to continue to be alive when I am only a bunch of bones.
I detest continuing to be alive; I do not want to live for many more years.
Allow me to be alone, because I will be alive for only a very short time.
We human beings are not very important;
so why do you pay so much attention to us ?
You look at us every morning to see what we are doing,
and you
When will you stop looking at me and leave me alone for a little time, long enough to swallow my own spit?
Why do you watch me constantly?
If I sin, that certainly does not harm you!
Why have you set me up like a target to shoot at?
Do you consider me to be a heavy load that you are forced to carry?
If I have sinned, are you not able to forgive me
for the wrong things that I have done?
Soon I will lie in my grave;
you will search for me, but you will not find me because I will be dead and gone."
Then Bildad, from the Shuah area, spoke to Job. He said,
"Job, how much longer will you talk like this?
What you say is as useless as a big wind.
Almighty God certainly never does anything unfairly.
He always does what is right.
Your children have sinned against him;
this is evident because he has punished them for those evil things.
But now, if only you will earnestly request Almighty God to help you!
If only you were pure and honest!
Then he will surely do something good for you
and reward you by giving your family back to you and making you prosper.
Even though you were not very prosperous before,
during the last stage of your life you would become very wealthy.
I request you to think about what happened long ago
and to consider what our ancestors found out.
It seems as though we were born only yesterday
and we know very little;
our time here on the earth disappears quickly, like a shadow that is here and then gone.
So why not allow your ancestors to teach you anything?
Let them tell you what they learned!
Papyrus certainly does not grow away from marshland;
reeds certainly cannot grow where there is no water.
If the water dries up while they are blossoming,
they wither more quickly than any other plant.
Those who do not pay attention to what God says are like those reeds;
godless people stop confidently expecting that good things will happen to them.
The things they confidently expect to happen do not happen;
things they trust will help them are as weak as a spider's web.
If they think they will be safe because they are wealthy, they will not be safe;
the things they think will keep them safe—those things will disappear.
Godless people are like plants that are watered before the sun rises:
their shoots spread all over the gardens.
The roots of those plants twist around the piles of stones
and cling tightly to the rocks.
But if a gardener pulls those plants out,
it is as though the place where they were planted says, 'They were never here!'
That is what happens to wicked people who do not pay attention to what God says.
Truly, this is all the joy that evil people have:
other people just come and take their places.
So, I tell you, Job, God will not reject you if you honor him,
but he does not help evil people.
He will always enable you to laugh
and to
But those who hate you will be very ashamed,
and the homes of wicked people will disappear."
Then Job replied,
"Yes, yes, I know.
But how can anyone say to God, 'I am innocent'?
If someone wanted to argue with God about that,
God could ask him a thousand questions
and that person would not be able to answer any of them!
God is very wise and powerful;
no one who has tried to argue against him has ever been able to win.
He even moves mountains in earthquakes without telling anyone in advance.
When he is angry, he turns the mountains upside down.
He sends earthquakes that shake the ground;
he causes the columns that support the earth to shake.
Some days he speaks to the sun, and it does not rise,
and some nights he prevents the stars from shining.
He alone stretched [stretches] out the sky;
he alone puts his feet on the waves and stops their violence.
He set in their places the groups of stars— the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades, and the groups of stars in the southern sky.
He does great things that we cannot understand;
he does more marvelous things than we are able to count.
He passes by where I am, but I cannot see him;
he moves further on, but I do not see him go.
If he wants to snatch someone away, no one could stop him;
no one dares ask him, 'Why are you doing that?'
God will not very easily stop being angry;
he defeated the servants of Rahab, the great sea monster.
If God took me to court,
what could I say to answer him?
Even though I would be innocent, I would not be able to answer him.
All I could do would be to request God, my judge, to act mercifully toward me.
If I summoned him to come to the courtroom and he said that he would come,
I would not believe that he would pay attention to what I would say.
He sends storms to batter me,
and he bruises me many times without any reason.
It is as though he will not let me get my breath
because he causes me to suffer all the time.
If I tried to wrestle with him, there would be no way to defeat him,
because he is stronger than I am.
If I called him to appear in court,
there is no one who could force him to go there.
Even though I was innocent, anything I said would cause him to punish me;
even though I had not done anything wrong, he would still prove that I was guilty.
I have not done anything wrong, but that is not important anymore because I do not care what happens to me.
I despise living.
Nothing is important to me
because God will get rid of all of us, both those who are innocent and those who are wicked.
When people experience disaster and it causes them to suddenly die,
God laughs at it, even if they are innocent.
God has allowed wicked people to control what happens in the world.
It is as though he had caused judges to be blind, no longer able to judge fairly.
If it is not God who has done that,
who, then, has done it?
My days pass very quickly, like a fast runner who passes one by;
it is as though the days run away, and nothing good ever happens to me.
My life goes by very rapidly, like a swiftly sailing boat made from reeds
or like an eagle that swoops down to seize an animal.
If I smile and say to God, 'I will forget what I am complaining about;
I will stop looking sad and try to be cheerful,'
then I become afraid because of all that I am suffering
because I know that God does not consider that I am innocent.
He will condemn me anyway,
so why should I keep trying in vain to defend myself?
If I washed myself with snow
or cleansed my hands with lye
to get rid of my guilt,
he would still throw me into a filthy pit;
as a result it would be as though even my clothes would detest me.
God is not a human, as I am,
so there is no way that I could answer him to prove that I am innocent
if we went together to have a trial in a courtroom.
There is no one to mediate,
no one who has authority over both of us.
I wish someone else could stop God from making me suffer,
and that he would not continue to terrify me.
If he did that, I would declare that I am innocent without being afraid of him
because I know within myself that I really have not done what is wrong like God thinks that I have.
I detest living any longer.
I will not stop saying why I am complaining.
Since I am very unhappy, I will speak.
I will say to God, 'Do not just say that you must punish me;
in addition, tell me what wrong you saw that I have done.
Does it please you to oppress me,
to abandon me, whom you created,
and, at the same time, to help wicked people to do the things that they plan to do?
Do you understand things the way that we humans do?
Do you live for only a few years, like [as] we do?
So why do you continue to search for my faults
and to hunt for my sins?
You know that I am not guilty,
and that no one can rescue me from your power.
With your hands you created me and shaped my body,
but now you are deciding that you should not have done that, and you are destroying me instead.
Do not forget that you made me from a piece of clay;
are you going to cause me to become soil again?
You certainly formed me when I was conceived,
and you put me together inside my mother's womb.
You fastened my bones together with sinews,
and then you covered them with flesh inside my skin.
You have caused me to be alive; you have faithfully loved me,
and you have carefully preserved me.
But you kept secret what you were planning to do to me;
I am certain that you were planning to do these things to me.
You were watching to see if I would sin,
so that, if I did sin, you would refuse to forgive me.
If I am a wicked man, I hope that terrible things will happen to me.
But even if I am righteous, I still must bow my head and feel ashamed
because I am very disgraced and feel miserable.
And if I am proud, you hunt me like a lion hunts for some animal to kill,
and you act powerfully to injure me.
You constantly find more witnesses to testify that I have done what is wrong,
and you continually become more angry with me.
It is as though you are [were] always bringing new troops to attack me.
God, why did you allow me to be born?
I wish had died when I was born, and that no one had ever seen me.
I think it would have been better if I had been carried directly from my mother's womb to the grave
than for me to live.
I think that there are only a few days for me to remain alive;
so allow me to be alone, in order that I may have a little peace
before I go to the place from which I will never return,
[a place] where it is always gloomy and very dark,
a place of darkness and dark shadows where everything is confused
[and] where even the small light there is like darkness.'"
Then Zophar, the friend from the region of Naamah, said this to Job:
"Should no one answer all that you have said?
Just because you talk a lot, that fact should not persuade us to declare that you are innocent.
Job, should your babbling really cause us to be silent?
When you make fun of what we think, certainly there should be someone to rebuke you and cause you to be ashamed!
You say, 'What I say is true;
God knows that I am innocent.'
But I wish that God would talk
and say something to answer you!
God knows everything about everything,
so I wish that he would tell you the secrets that he knows because he is wise.
It would be good if you realized that God is punishing you less than you deserve!
Tell me, will you ever be able to find out the things about God that are very difficult to understand?
Will you be able to find out everything that there is to know about Almighty God?
What there is to know about God is greater than the distance from earth to heaven;
so there is no way that you can understand it all.
It is greater than the distance from here to the place of the dead;
so it is impossible for you to know it all.
What there is to know about God is wider than the earth
and wider than the ocean.
If God comes to you and puts you in prison and then brings you to a trial,
who can stop him?
He knows which people are worthless;
and when he sees people doing wicked things, he certainly does not ignore them.
Stupid people like you will start to become wise
when wild donkeys start giving birth to people.
Job, repent and make your heart humble;
reach out your hands toward God and plead with him.
If you have done evil things, stop doing them;
and do not allow any people in your house to do wicked deeds.
If you do that, surely you will be able to carry your head high, because you will not be ashamed;
you will be strong and not afraid of anything.
You will forget all your troubles;
they will be like the water that has all flowed away and dried up.
Your troubles will be ended, like the darkness ends at the dawn;
it will be as though the sun were shining brightly on you, like it shines at noon.
You will feel safe, because you will be confident that good things will happen to you;
God will protect you and allow you to rest safely each night.
You will lie down to sleep, and no one will make you afraid.
And many people will come and request you to be kind to them.
But wicked people will not be able to understand why bad things are happening to them;
they will not have any way to escape from their troubles.
The only thing that they will want to do is to die. "
Then Job said to his three friends,
"There is no doubt that you are the people to whom everyone should listen,
and that when you die, there will be no more wise people alive.
But I have as much good sense as you do;
I am no less wise than you are.
Certainly everyone knows all that you have said.
My friends all laugh at me now.
Previously I habitually requested God to help me, and he always answered me.
I am righteous, and I honor God, but now everyone laughs at me.
It is easy for people like you, who have no troubles, to laugh at people like me;
you make us who are already suffering to have even more troubles.
Meanwhile, bandits live peacefully,
and no one threatens those who cause God to become angry;
the god they worship is their own strength.
But ask the wild animals what they know about God;
if they could speak they would teach you.
If you could ask the birds,
they would tell you.
If you could ask the creatures that crawl on the ground, or the fish in the sea,
they would tell you about God.
All of them certainly know that it is Yahweh who has done this.
He directs the lives of all living creatures;
he gives breath to all us humans to enable us to live.
When we hear what people like you say,
we think carefully about what they say to determine what is good and what is bad,
like we taste food to know what is good and what is bad.
Old people are usually very wise;
because they have lived a long time, they understand much.
And God is wise and very powerful;
he has good sense and understands everything.
If he tears something down, no one can rebuild it;
if he puts someone in prison, no one can open the door to let that person to escape.
When he prevents rain from falling, everything dries up.
When he causes a lot of rain to fall, the result is that there are floods.
He is the one who is truly strong and wise;
he rules over those who deceive others and those whom they deceive.
He sometimes causes the king's officials to lose their wisdom and grieve because of it'
and he causes judges to become foolish.
He takes from kings the ornaments that they wear
and puts loincloths around their waists, causing them to become slaves.
He also makes priests grieve,
and he takes power away from those who rule others.
He sometimes causes those whom others trust to be unable to speak,
and he causes old men to no longer have good sense.
He causes people to despise those who rule,
and he causes those who are powerful to become weak.
He shows to us things that were secret,
even things that were in the world of the dead.
He causes some nations to become very great,
and later he destroys them;
he causes the territory of some nations to become much larger,
and later he brings others to defeat them and take them prisoner.
He causes some rulers to become foolish,
and then he causes them to wander around, lost, as if they were in the wilderness with no way out.
It is as if they were feeling around in the darkness, without any light;
as if they were drunk, not knowing what they should do."
"I have seen everything that you have seen,
and I have heard and understood all that you have said.
What you know, I also know;
I do not know less than you.
But I would like to speak with Almighty God, not with you;
I would like to argue with him and show him that I am innocent.
As for you, you tell lies and do not allow people to know unpleasant truth,
like someone who covers up the bad surface of a wall with whitewash.
You are all like doctors who sell people useless medicine.
I wish that you would be silent;
that would be wiser than anything you have said to me.
Listen to what I will say to you now;
listen while I am saying what is true about myself.
You are telling lies to help God;
you are saying what is false in order to help him!
You would really like to be kind to him by defending what he does, would you not?
It is as if you were trying to prove in a court that he is innocent!
But if he, sitting as the judge, looked closely at you, he would find that what you are doing for him is bad!
You have deceived other people, but do not think that you can lie about him in court and say that you are defending him!
If you say clever things to persuade God to take your side,
he will surely rebuke you.
He will certainly bring the full force of his power against you;
you will become very afraid of him.
What you have said—the things that you think are so wise—are as useless as ashes;
what you say to defend how you think is no better than clay that quickly crumbles.
So be quiet and allow me to speak;
after that, it will not matter what happens to me.
I am ready to risk my life;
I am even willing to risk that God will execute me for what I say.
If he kills me, then I will not have anyone else whom I can confidently expect to help me,
but I am going to defend my behavior in his presence anyway.
No wicked person would dare to stand in the presence of God,
but because I say that I have not done things that are wrong,
perhaps, if I can prove that to God, he will declare me innocent."
"God, listen very carefully to what I say; pay attention to me.
I am ready to argue that I am innocent,
and I know that you also will declare that I am not guilty.
I certainly do not think that you or anyone else will say that what I say is false;
if you did so, then I would speak no more, and I would die.
I am requesting you to do two things for me;
if you do them, I will not try to hide from you.
The first thing that I request is that you stop punishing me,
and the second thing that I request is that you stop terrifying me.
Speak first, and then I will reply;
or allow me to speak first, and then you reply.
What have I done that is wrong? What sins have I committed?
Show me how I have disobeyed you.
Why do you refuse to be friendly to me?
Why do you act toward me as though I were your enemy?
I am as insignificant as a leaf that the wind blows.
Why are you trying to make me afraid ?
Why are you making me suffer?
After all, I am as useless as a bit of dry chaff!
It seems that you are writing things to accuse me of having sinned,
and that you are writing down even the bad things I did when I was young.
It is as though you have put my feet in stocks
and that you were watching me wherever I walk;
it is as though you were following my footprints to see where I have gone.
Because of this, my body is falling apart like rotten wood,
like a piece of cloth that the larvae of moths are eating.
We humans are very frail. We are born, and
we live only a short time; we experience much trouble.
We disappear quickly, like flowers that grow from the ground quickly and then wither and die.
We are like shadows that disappear when the sun stops shining.
Yahweh, why do you keep watching me to see if I am doing something that is wrong ?
Do you want to take me to court to judge me?
No one can bring something acceptable to God out of something that is not acceptable to him.
You have decided how long our lives will be.
You have decided how many months we will live,
and we cannot live longer than the time that you have decided.
So please stop examining us, and allow us to be alone
so that we might enjoy our life of hard labor, if a hired worker can possibly do so.
If we cut a tree down,
sometimes we hope that it will sprout again and grow new branches.
Its roots in the ground may be very old,
and its stump may decay,
but if some water falls on it,
it may bud and send up shoots like a young plant.
But when we people lose all our strength and die,
we stop breathing, and then we are gone forever.
Just as water evaporates from a lake,
or as a riverbed dries up,
people lie down and die and do not get up again.
Until the heavens do not exist any longer;
people who die do not wake up,
and no one can wake them up.
Yahweh, I wish that you would put me safely in the place of the dead and forget about me, so that I do not suffer any more
until you are no longer angry with me.
I wish that you would decide how much time I would spend there,
and then remember that I am there.
When we humans die, we will certainly not live again.
If I knew that we would live again, I would wait patiently
for you to release me from my sufferings.
You would call me, and I would answer.
You would be eager to see me, one of the creatures that you had made.
You would carefully see where I went,
and you would not be interested in seeing whether I sinned or not.
The record of my sins would be sealed in a small bag,
and you would cover them.
But, just as mountains crumble and rocks fall down from a cliff,
and just as water slowly wears away the stones, and just as floods wash away soil,
you eventually destroy us; you do not allow us to continue to hope that we will keep on living.
You always defeat us, and then we die.
You cause our faces to look ugly after we die,
and you send us away.
When we die, we do not know if our sons will grow up and do things that will cause other people to honor them.
Or if they become disgraced, we do not know that either.
We will feel our own pain; we will not feel anything else;
we will be sorry for ourselves, not for anyone else."
Then Eliphaz replied to Job:
"If you were truly wise, you would not have replied to us by claiming that you know a lot;
what you are saying is just a lot of hot air.
You should not be saying things that do not benefit anyone;
you should not say things that do no one any good.
You are teaching others not to respect God,
and you are keeping them from honoring him.
You are wicked, and that is why you say what you do;
you talk like deceptive people talk.
Everything that you say shows that God should punish you;
it is not necessary for me to prove that.
Tell me, why do you think you know so much? You do not think that you were the first person who was ever born, do you?
You do not think that you were born before God created the mountains, do you?
Were you listening when God made all his plans?
Do you think that you are the only person who is wise?
What do you know that we others do not know?
You do not understand anything that is not also clear to us.
My friends and I are also wise;
we acquired wisdom from old gray-haired people,
from people who were born before your father was.
God wants to comfort you
and to speak gently to you;
that should be enough for you, but it is not enough, is it?
Why do you allow yourself to be excited by your emotions?
Why do your eyes flash with anger?
You are angry with God,
and so you say harsh things against him.
How can any person, including you, be sinless?
How can anyone on the earth be completely righteous?
God does not even trust his angels;
he does not consider the heavens to be completely pure.
So he certainly does not trust disgusting people,
those who commit evil deeds as often as they drink water.
Job, listen to what I tell you.
I will declare to you what I know,
things that wise men have told me,
truths that their ancestors did not keep hidden.
(God gave this land to those ancestors who were truly wise;
no one from another country came and caused them to think wrongly about God.)
Wicked people suffer with great pain all the time that they are alive;
that is what happens to those who oppress others.
They constantly hear sounds that terrify them;
while they are prospering, robbers attack them.
Wicked people do not really think that they will escape from darkness;
they are sure that someone is waiting to kill them with a sword.
They wander around, searching for food, saying 'Where can I find some?'
They know that they will soon experience disasters.
Because they are afraid of those things happening to them, they worry
that these things will attack them as a king's army waits to attack its enemies and causes them to suffer.
These things happen to them because they shook their fists against Almighty God
and thought that they were strong enough to defeat him.
They stubbornly rush to attack God
thinking that a strong shield will protect them.
But they are so fat that they are unable to fight.
They have lived in cities that have been abandoned,
cities which God declared would become a heap of ruins.
But they will not remain rich very long;
Others will take everything that they own,
and even their shadows will disappear from the earth.
They will not escape from the darkness of death;
they will be like trees whose branches burn up.
When God gives the command, they will die.
If they are very foolish, with the result that they trust in things that are really worthless,
then things that are worthless will be all that they get.
While they are still young, they will disappear;
they will be like branches that wither and never become green again.
They will be like vines whose grapes fall off before they are ripe,
like olive trees whose blossoms fall off before they produce any fruit.
Groups of wicked people will not have any descendants,
and fires will completely burn up the homes of those who took money from bribes.
They plan to cause trouble and to do evil things,
and in their hearts they are always preparing to deceive people."
Job replied to Eliphaz and the others,
"I have heard things like that before;
all of you, instead of helping me, are only causing me to feel more miserable.
Will your speeches, which are only wind, never end?
Eliphaz, what bothers you that makes you continue replying like this to me?
If it were you three and not I who were suffering,
I could, in your place, say the things that you are saying.
I could make great speeches to criticize you,
and I could shake my head at you to ridicule you.
Then you would see whether my words encouraged you or not;
you would see whether they made you feel your pain less.
But now, if I talk, my pain does not decrease,
and if I am silent, my pain still certainly does not go away.
God, you have now taken away all my strength;
you have destroyed all my family.
You have shriveled me up,
and people think that shows me to be a sinner.
They see that I am only skin and bones,
and they think that proves that I am guilty.
Because God is very angry with me and hates me,
it is as though he were a wild animal that tore me apart with his teeth
because he was my enemy.
People gape at me with their mouths open to sneer at me;
they have struck me on the face to ridicule me,
and they crowd around me to threaten me.
It is as though God has handed me over to people who refuse to honor him
and has put me into the power of the wicked.
Previously, I was living peacefully,
but he crushed me;
it is as though he grabbed my neck and smashed me to pieces;
it is as though he set me up like a target.
It is as though I were a target, and that people were surrounding me and shooting arrows at me.
God's arrows pierce my kidneys
and cause the bile from my liver to spill onto the ground;
God does not pity me at all.
It is as though I were a wall that he is breaking through time after time;
he rushes at me like a soldier who is attacking his enemy.
Because I am mourning, I wear pieces of rough cloth that I have sewed together,
and I sit here in the dirt, very depressed.
My face is red because I have cried very much,
and there are dark circles around my eyes.
All this has happened to me even though I have not acted violently toward anyone,
and even though I always pray sincerely to God.
When I die, I want the ground to act as though I had been murdered;
and I do not want anyone to stop me while I am demanding that God act justly toward me.
But even now, I know that there is someone in heaven who will testify for me,
and he will say that what I have done is right.
My three friends scorn me,
but my eyes are full of tears while I cry out to God.
I pray that the one who knows what I have done would come to plead with God for me
as a person pleads for his friend.
I say this because within a few years I will die;
I will walk along the road to a place from which I will never return."
"My time to live is almost ended; I have no strength left;
those who have dug my grave are waiting for me.
Those who are around me are making fun of me;
I must always see them mocking me."
"God, it is as though I were in prison;
please pay the money in order that I may be released,
because there is certainly no one else who will help me.
You have prevented my friends from understanding what is true about me,
but you will not allow them to triumph over me, saying that I have done wrong things.
Our ancestors said, 'It often happens that when someone betrays his friends in order to get some of their property,
it is that person's children who will be punished for it;'
so I desire that will be true of these friends of mine who are lying about me.
But now people use that saying of our ancestors when they talk about me;
they spit to insult me.
My eyes have become dim because I am very sad,
and my arms and legs are as thin as shadows.
People who are truly righteous will be shocked when they see what has happened to me;
they will be angry at those who refuse to honor God.
Those who are truly righteous will continue to do what is right,
and those who live righteously will continue to become stronger.
But all you friends of mine,
I do not find even one among you who is wise.
My time to live is almost ended; I have not been able to do the things that I planned to do.
As for the things I have most desired, there is no hope of them happening.
My friends do not know when it is night and when it is day;
when it is night, they claim that it is daylight;
when it is becoming dark, they claim that it is getting light.
I know that my home will be the place where dead people are,
where I will sleep in the darkness.
I can say to the grave, 'Where I am buried, that place will be like a father to me.'
I can say to the maggots, 'You will be like a mother or younger sisters to me because that is where I will always be.'
There is certainly no more hope left for me.
No one expects that I will have any more happiness.
After I descend to the place where the dead are, I will not be able to expect anything good there.
I and the things I hope for will go down together into the soil."
Then Bildad replied again:
"Please stop talking!
If you would stop talking and listen, we could tell you something.
Why do you think that we are as stupid as cattle and as unrighteous?
By being very angry, you are only hurting yourself.
Do you think that everyone on the earth must leave to prove that you are right,
or do you think that God must move the rocks in the mountains to please you?
What will happen is that the lives of wicked people like you end
as quickly as we can put out a light or extinguish the flame of a fire.
When the lamps above them in their tents are extinguished,
there will be no light in those tents.
While they are alive, they walk confidently,
but later it will be as though they stumbled and fell,
because they themselves do not pay attention to the advice that they give to others.
It will be as though they had walked into their own net
or had fallen into a pit that they themselves dug.
It will be as though a trap had grabbed their heels and held them fast,
as though the end of a rope that was hidden on the ground
had sprung up and seized them when they walked on it.
Everywhere they go, there will be things that cause them to be terrified;
it will be as though those things were pursuing them and biting at their heels.
They will become hungry, with the result that they will be strong no longer.
They will continually experience disasters.
Diseases will spread all over their skin;
diseases will cause their bodies to decay.
When they die, they will be snatched away from their tents
and brought to the one who rules over the dead.
Then other people will live in their tents,
but only after they sprinkle sulfur on those tents to get rid of the disease!
Because they will die and leave no descendants,
they will be like trees whose roots have dried up and whose branches have all withered.
No one on the earth will remember them anymore;
no one on any street will even remember their names.
They will have to leave the earth, where there is light,
and rush into the place where it is dark.
They will have no children or grandchildren,
no descendants where they will have previously lived.
People from the east to the west who hear about what happened to them, everyone,
will be shocked and horrified.
This is what happens to unrighteous people like you,
people who do not know God."
Then Job replied:
"How long will you three torment me
and discourage me by calling me wicked?
You have insulted me many times;
are you not ashamed for saying these things to me?
Even if it were true that I had done wrong,
I have not injured you!
If you truly think that you are better than I am,
and if you argue that I must be guilty because I am suffering,
you should realize that it is God who has caused me to suffer.
It is as though he has a net and that he has caught me in it.
I cry out, 'People are murdering me!',
but no one answers me.
I call out loudly, but there is no one, not even God, who acts fairly toward me.
It is as though God has blocked my road,
and I cannot go anywhere;
it is as though he has forced me to try to find the road in the darkness.
He has taken away my good reputation;
it is as though he has removed a crown from my head.
He batters me from every side, and I will soon die.
I no longer expect him to do anything good for me.
He attacks me because he is very angry at me;
he considers me to be his enemy.
It is as though he were sending his army to attack me;
they surround my tent
and get ready to attack me.
God has caused my brothers to abandon me,
and for all those who know me to act like strangers to me.
All my relatives and good friends have left me.
The people who were guests in my house have forgotten me,
and my female servants consider that I am a foreigner whom they do not know.
When I summon my servants, they do not answer;
When I plead with them to come to help me, they do not come.
My breath smells very bad to my wife so she stays away from me,
and my brothers detest me.
Even young children despise me;
when I stand up to talk to them, they laugh at me.
My dearest friends detest me,
and those whom I love very much have turned against me.
My body is only skin and bones;
I am barely alive.
I plead with you, my three friends, pity me
because God has struck me very hard.
Why do you cause me to suffer, also? Do you think you are God?
Why do you never get enough of accusing me of doing wrong?
I wish that someone would take these words of mine
and write them permanently in a book in order that people can read them.
Or else, I wish that someone would carve my words on a rock with a chisel
in order that they would last forever.
But I know that the one who vindicates me in court is alive,
and that some day he will stand here on the earth and make the final decision about whether I deserve to be punished.
And even after diseases have destroyed my body,
still, in my body I will see God.
I will see him myself;
I will see him with my own eyes!
My emotions overwhelm me as I think about that!
If you three men say, 'This is how we will cause him to suffer!'
and you say, 'He is the one who has caused his own troubles,'
you should fear that God will punish you;
he punishes those like you with whom he is angry;
and when that happens, you will know that there is someone who judges people."
Then Zophar replied again:
"I am very troubled about what you have said,
so I want to reply very quickly.
By saying these things you have insulted me,
but something within my understanding suggests to me how I may reply to you.
Do you not know that from long ago,
ever since God first put people on the earth,
that wicked people like you do not continue to rejoice for a long time,
and that people who refuse to honor God are happy only for a moment?
Although their reputations reach up to the sky,
and their fame goes up as high as the clouds,
they will disappear forever, like their own excrement,
and those who knew them will ask, 'Where did they go?'
They will disappear as a dream does,
and they will exist no more.
They will vanish like dreams that people have during the night.
Those people who now see those wicked people will never see them again;
even the people who lived with them will not see them anymore.
Their children will be forced to return the valuable things that they stole from poor people.
The bodies of the wicked were once young and strong,
but they will die and be buried in the ground.
Although doing wicked things was like having sweet food in their mouths
that they wanted to continue tasting,
and although they did not want to stop doing those things,
those evil things will someday become like poison that they swallow,
or like the poison from snakes.
Wicked people pile up wealth for themselves, but they do not keep it forever,
just like people do not keep down the food that they vomit.
God takes their wealth from them.
Doing evil deeds is like swallowing snake poison;
doing evil will kill the wicked as the bite of a poisonous snake will kill people.
The wicked will not remain alive to see the abundant blessings from God,
which are like a stream that flows.
They will be forced to give back the things that they stole from the poor;
they will not be able to continue to enjoy those things.
They will not remain happy because of what they got from their business
because they oppressed poor people and refused to help them,
and they took other people's houses by cheating them.
They were always greedy and never satisfied.
So when they ate, they ate so much that they never saved anything that they enjoyed.
When they finished eating their food, there was never anything left over because they had greedily eaten it all;
but now their prosperity will end.
When they are still very wealthy,
they will suddenly experience trouble.
The full power of everyone who lives in misery will crush them.
When the wicked people are filling their stomachs,
God will show that he is very angry with them, and he will punish them;
he will bring down suffering on them like the rain that falls on the ground.
They will try to escape from people who will attack them with iron weapons,
but arrows with bronze points will pierce them.
The arrows will go completely through their bodies and stick out of their backs;
the shiny points of the arrows will have blood dripping from them,
and those wicked people will be terrified.
Their valuable possessions will all be destroyed;
a fire started by God, not by humans, will burn them up
and will destroy the things that are left in their tents.
The angels in heaven will reveal the sins that those wicked people have committed,
and people on earth will stand up and testify against them.
On the day when God punishes people,
all the possessions in the wicked people's houses will be carried away, as if a flood had come.
That is what will happen to wicked people like you;
that is what God has decreed for them."
Then Job replied in this way:
"Listen to what I say, all of you;
that is the only thing that you can do that will comfort me.
Be patient with me, and allow me to speak.
Then, after I am finished speaking, you can continue to make fun of me.
It is certainly not people against whom I am complaining, but God!
And it is certainly right for me to be impatient!
Look at me! Does what you see not cause you to be appalled
and to put your hands over your mouths and say no more?
When I think about what has happened to me,
I am frightened and my entire body shakes.
But allow me to ask this: 'Why do wicked people continue to live,
and become prosperous, and not die until they are very old?'
They see their children around them,
and they watch them while they grow up and start to live in their own houses.
Wicked people live in their own houses without being afraid,
and God does not punish them.
Their bulls always mate with the cows successfully,
and the cows always give birth to calves and never miscarry.
Wicked people send their young children outside to play,
and the children jump around happily like lambs in a pasture.
The children sing to the sound of tambourines and lyres,
and they are happy to hear the sound of flutes.
Wicked people enjoy having good things all the time that they are alive,
and they die quietly and go down to the place of the dead.
While they are alive, they say to God, 'Leave us alone;
we do not care about how you desire us to conduct our lives!
Why do you, Almighty God, think that we should serve you?
What advantage do we get if we pray to you?'
Wicked people think that they have become prosperous because of what they have done,
but I do not want to have anything to do with their thinking.
How often does it happen that wicked people die,
without experiencing disasters?
Does God ever punish them because he is angry with them?
He does not blow them away as wind blows away straw;
they are never carried off by a whirlwind.
You say, 'When people have committed sins,
God waits and punishes their children because of those sins;'
I say that God should punish those who sin, not their children,
in order that the sinners may know that it is because of their own sins that they are being punished.
I hope that wicked people will live to experience God destroying them,
that they will experience Almighty God punishing them.
After wicked people are dead,
they are not at all concerned for their families who are still alive.
Since God judges everyone, even those who are in heaven,
who can teach him anything?
Some people die while they are very healthy,
while they are peaceful and not afraid of anything.
Their bodies are fat;
their bones are strong.
Other people die being very miserable;
they have never experienced good things happening to them.
They die and are buried,
and maggots cover their bodies.
Everyone dies, so it is clear that dying is not always the punishment for being wicked.
Listen, I know what you three are thinking,
and I know the evil things that you plan to do to me.
You say, 'What happened to the tents in which wicked people were living?
The houses of evil rulers have been destroyed!'
Have you never asked people who travel much?
Do you not believe their reports about what they have seen,
that wicked people usually do not suffer at the time when there are great disasters;
that when God punishes people, someone rescues the wicked? that wicked people are the ones whom someone else rescues when God punishes people?
There is no one who accuses wicked people,
and there is no one who pays them back for all the evil things that they have done.
When the corpses of wicked people are carried to their graves,
people are put there to guard those graves.
A huge number of people go to the grave site;
some go in front of the procession and some come behind,
and the wicked ones who have died surely feel good when people throw clods of dirt on their graves.
So how can you comfort me by talking nonsense?
Every reply that you give me is full of lies!"
Then Eliphaz replied, saying this:
"No one can be useful to God!
People who are wise can be useful to themselves, but not to God.
If you were righteous, that would not please Almighty God, would it?
If you lived a perfect life, that would not help him, would it?
Do you honor God, and is that why he punishes you?
Is that the reason that he puts you on trial?
No, it certainly must be because you are extremely wicked.
It must be that no one can count the evil things that you have done!
You must have lent money to others and wrongly forced them to give you things to guarantee that they would pay that money back to you;
you must have taken all their clothes and left them with nothing to wear.
You must not have given water to those who were thirsty,
and you must have refused to give food to those who were hungry.
Because you were very powerful, you must have taken over all the people's land,
and then you began to live on that land, even though others honored you very much.
When widows came to you for help, you must have sent them away without giving them anything,
and you must have oppressed orphans.
Because you did all those things, now there are traps that will catch you;
now things appear that terrify you and cause you to tremble.
It is as though it had become very dark, with the result that you cannot see anything,
and it is as though a flood covered you.
But consider this, Job: God lives high up in the heavens.
From there he looks down on the highest stars.
So why do you say, 'God knows nothing about what we are doing'?
And why do you say, 'Dark clouds keep him from seeing us, so he cannot judge us'?
Do you think that while he walks on the dome that covers the sky,
where there are thick clouds around him, he cannot see what we do?'
Will you, Job, continue to conduct your life in the old way
that evil people have done for many years?
They suddenly died while they were still young;
they disappeared like everything disappears when there is a flood .
They kept saying to God, 'Leave us alone,' 'Allow us to be alone,'
and they also said defiantly, 'Almighty God can do nothing to harm us!'
Yet it was God who filled their houses with good things;
so I cannot agree at all to follow what the wicked plan.
When righteous people see that God punishes wicked people, they are glad,
and they laugh at those wicked people.
They say, 'Now our enemies have been destroyed,
and fire has burned up anything left of their wealth.'
So, Job, be reconciled to God and make peace with him;
if you do that, good things will happen to you.
Allow him to teach you,
and put his words into your mind.
If you humble yourself and return to God, he will restore you;
if you stop doing all the evil things that you have been doing in your house,
and if you throw away your gold,
the fine gold from the dry stream beds in Ophir land,
then Almighty God will be to be as precious to you as your gold and your silver have been.
Then you will be happy because of God,
and you will be able to approach him confidently.
You will pray to him, and he will do what you request him to do;
you will do the things that you promised him that you would do.
Everything that you decide to do will be successful;
it will be as though a light were shining on the road in front of you.
God humbles those who are proud,
but he saves those who are downcast.
God rescues those who are not innocent;
they will be rescued because you do what is right."
Then Job replied and said this:
"Today I am again complaining bitterly to God;
I continue to groan, but I suffer even more.
I wish that I knew where I could meet with him
so that I could go to the place where he lives.
If I could do that, I would tell him why I know that I am innocent;
I would tell him many reasons for that.
Then I would find out and understand what he would reply to me.
Would he use his great power to argue with me?
No, he would listen to me carefully.
I am an honest man, so I would be able to discuss things with him fairly,
and then he would declare that I am innocent, and he would not trouble me again.
However, I have gone to the east, and he is not there;
I have gone to the west, but I have not found him there.
I have gone north and I have gone south,
but I have not seen him anywhere for he keeps himself from me.
He knows how I have conducted my life;
when he has finished testing me, he will see that I am as pure as gold whose impurities have all been burned out.
I have faithfully walked on the road that he showed me;
I have not turned away from obeying him.
I have always obeyed what he commanded;
I have hidden away in my inner being the words that he has spoken.
He never changes. There is no one who can stop him from doing what he desires.
Whatever he wants to do, he does.
He will finish doing the things that he has planned for me,
and I am sure that he has thought about doing many things for me.
So I am terrified when I am in front of him;
when I think about what he can do, I am very afraid.
Almighty God has made me very afraid.
The thick darkness in front of me has not make me silent,
even that terrible darkness that covers my face has not kept me from speaking."
"Why does Almighty God not set a time when he will judge evil people?
The people who obey God never seem to see him judge the evil people.
Some evil people remove the boundary markers of other people's land, in order to take their land;
they seize other people's sheep and put them in their own pastures.
Some take away the donkeys that belong to orphans,
and they take widows' oxen to guarantee that the widows will pay back the money that they loaned to those widows.
Some shove poor people off the road,
and they force poor people to find places to hide from them.
The result is that poor people have to search for food in the desert plain
like wild donkeys do.
The poor people harvest leftover grain in other people's fields,
and gather leftover grapes from vineyards that belong to wicked men.
During the night they have nothing to cover their bodies,
nothing to keep them warm.
When it rains in the mountains, they become very wet,
so they huddle under the rock ledges to protect themselves from the rain.
Some evil men snatch poor, fatherless infants away from their mothers;
they say 'I will return your babies to you when you repay the money that I lent to you.'
But the poor people walk around with no clothes on;
they are hungry while they are working to carry other people's bundles of grain to the places where their grain will be threshed.
Poor people are hired by these wicked people to make olive oil for them;
they tread on grapes to make juice for wine,
but they are not allowed to drink any of it when they are thirsty.
In the cities, people who are wounded and dying cry out to God for help,
but God ignores their prayers.
Some wicked people avoid the light because they do evil things in the dark;
they do not walk on roads that are lit.
Murderers steal things during the night,
and then they rise before dawn in order that they may go out again and kill poor and needy people.
Those who want to commit adultery wait for evening to come;
they say, 'I do not want anyone to see me,' so they keep their faces covered.
It is during the night that robbers break into houses to steal things,
but during the day they hide because they want to avoid being seen in the light.
All of those people want to do their evil deeds at night, not in the morning when it is light,
because they are not afraid of the things that happen during the night that terrify others.
However, those wicked people will disappear very quickly,
and God will curse the land that they owned;
no one will go any longer to work in their vineyards.
Just as the snow melts away when it is hot and there is no rain,
those who have sinned will disappear into the place where the dead people are.
Not even their mothers will remember them;
wicked people will be destroyed like trees that are cut down,
and maggots will eat their corpses.
The wicked mistreat women who have been unable to give birth to children who would have grown up to take care of them;
the wicked they never help widows.
But God, by his power, gets rid of mighty people.
He causes the wicked people to die.
God allows them to think that they are secure and safe,
but he is watching them all the time.
They prosper for a little while,
and then suddenly they are gone;
God will make them die like all the other people;
they will be like stalks of grain that the farmers have cut off.
If this is not true, is there anyone who will show that I am a liar
and prove me wrong?"
Then Bildad also replied:
"God is very powerful; everyone should honor him very much;
he causes everything to be peaceful high up in heaven, with no confusion at all.
Can anyone count the angels who are in his army in heaven?
Is there any person on whom his light does not shine?
So how can God consider any person to be righteous?
How can he accept any human being?
Consider this: God does not even think that the full moon is bright,
and he does not even accept the stars in the heavens as worthy of him.
So what about humans?
They are as insignificant as maggots.
God does not think more highly of people than he thinks of worms."
Job replied to Bildad:
"I am a very weak and helpless man;
you do not really think that you have helped me at all, do you?
You certainly do not think that you have given me good advice, do you?—me, who am not wise at all.
Who helped you to say all those great things?
Who inspired you to speak like you did?
The spirits of dead people tremble with fear,
those who are under the waters
and everyone who dwells with them.
God knows all about those who are in the place of the dead;
there is nothing down there that prevents God from seeing what is there.
God stretches out heaven
over the empty spaces,
and he places the earth in that huge empty space, but it is not resting on anything.
He fills the thick clouds with water
and prevents that water from bursting the clouds.
He causes clouds to obscure the moon.
He separates the light from the darkness
and puts the horizon to mark the place where the night ends and the daytime begins.
When he is angry, it is as though he rebuked the pillars that hold up the sky.
They are shocked, and they tremble.
By his power he calmed the sea;
by his skill he destroyed Rahab, the huge sea monster.
By his breath he caused the sky to be bright;
by his hand he killed the great dragon in the sea as it was fleeing from him.
But those events show only a small amount of his power;
it is as though we were hearing only whispers of his powerful voice.
When we hear thunder, we say, 'Who can really understand how great his power is?'"
Job continued speaking to his three friends:
"Almighty God has refused to treat me justly.
He has caused me to feel bitter.
But just as surely as he lives,
I will say this as long as God's Spirit enables me to breathe!
I will not lie!
I will not say anything to deceive anyone.
I will never admit that what you three have said is true;
until the day that I die, I will insist that I have not done things that are wrong.
I will say that I am innocent, and I will never say anything different;
my inner being will never reproach me as long as I live.
I want God to punish my enemies like he will punish all wicked people;
I want him to punish those who oppose me like he punishes all unrighteous people.
When it is time for God to get rid of godless people and to cause them to die,
there is absolutely nothing good that they can confidently expect to happen to them.
When they experience troubles, God will not hear them call out to him for help, will he?
Will they be happy about what Almighty God does?
Will they begin to pray to him frequently?
Certainly not!
I will teach you three something about God's power;
I will reveal to you what he is thinking.
You three have seen for yourselves powerful things that God has done;
so I do not understand why you have been saying such nonsense to me.
I will tell you what Almighty God does to wicked people,
what he does to people who mistreat others.
Even if they have many children, those children will die in wars,
or they will die because they do not have enough food to eat.
Their children who are still alive after they themselves die will perish from diseases,
and the wives they leave behind will not even mourn for them.
Sometimes wicked people accumulate a huge amount of silver
and pile up clothes as potters pile up clay,
but those wicked people will die, and then righteous people will wear those clothes,
and honest people will get their silver and divide it among themselves.
The houses that they build are as weak as spider webs;
they are like flimsy huts that watchmen live in while they guard people's fields.
The wicked people are rich when they lie down at night,
but when they wake up in the morning, they find out that their money has disappeared.
Things that terrify them come to them like a flood that they do not expect;
during the night a whirlwind carries them away.
It is as though the wind from the east had picked them up and carried them away from their homes,
and they disappear forever.
That wind strikes them without pitying them
while they are running away, trying to escape from its force.
That wind is like someone clapping his hands at them to mock them,
howling at them and forcing them to run away."
"It is true that there are places where men dig to find silver,
and there are places where people refine gold that they have dug.
People dig iron ore out of the ground,
and they also smelt copper.
Men use lamps while they work far down under the ground
to search for the ore inside the mines
where it is very dark.
They dig shafts in places that are far from where people live,
where travelers do not go.
They work far away from other people,
swinging back and forth on ropes as they descend into the mine shafts.
Food grows on the surface of the ground,
but down under the ground, where there is no food, the miners make fires to break apart the rocks.
The stones that are dug from under the ground contain sapphires,
and the dirt contains bits of gold.
Some birds have very good eyes,
but even hawks do not know where the mines are,
and falcons have not seen those places.
Lions or other proud wild animals have never gone to those places.
Miners dig very hard rock;
it is as though they turned the mountains upside down to get the ore.
They cut tunnels through the rocks,
and they find precious things.
They dam up small streams to stop the water from flowing,
and they bring up into the light things that are hidden in the ground and in the streams.
But wisdom: Where can people find that?
Where can we find out how to truly understand things?
Humans do not know what wisdom is truly worth;
no one can find it here on this earth where they are living.
It is as though the water that is under the earth and water that is in the seas said,
'I do not have it!'
People cannot buy wisdom
by paying for it with silver or gold.
Wisdom is worth much more than fine gold from the land of Ophir,
much more than very valuable stones.
It is worth much more than gold or beautiful quartz;
wisdom is more expensive than the finest jewels, and it is worth more than a vase made with pure gold.
Wisdom is worth more than coral or crystal quartz;
the price of wisdom is higher than the price of rubies.
The prices of topaz from Ethiopia and of pure gold
are lower than the value of wisdom.
So from where does wisdom come?
Where can we find out how to truly understand things?
No living humans can see it;
and birds cannot see it while they are up in the sky.
It is as though the places where people go after they die said,
'We have only heard rumors about where to find wisdom.'
God is the only one who knows how to find wisdom;
he knows where it is
because he can see things even in the most remote places on the earth;
he can see everything that is below the sky.
He decided how strongly the winds should blow,
and how much rain should be in the clouds.
He decided where rain should fall,
and what path lightning should take from the clouds down to the ground.
At that time he saw wisdom and decided that it is very valuable.
He examined it and approved it.
And then he said to human beings, 'Listen! If you have much respect for me, you will be able to become wise;
to truly understand everything, you must first turn away from doing what is evil.'"
Job spoke again and said this:
"I wish that I could be as I was previously
during the years when God took care of me.
During those years, it was as though God's lamp shone on me
and gave me light while I walked in the darkness.
At that time I was young and strong,
and because God was my friend, he protected where I lived.
Almighty God was with me during those years
when all my children were around me.
My herds provided me with plenty of milk,
