and streams of oil flowed from the rock where my servants pressed the olives.
Whenever I went to the place where the elders gathered at the city gate,
I sat down with them,
and when the young men saw me, they stepped aside respectfully,
and the old men also stood respectfully.
The leaders of the people used to stop talking,
and even the most important men became quiet
and stopped talking in order to hear me speak to them.
When they all heard what I told them,
they said good things about me.
When they saw me, they always praised me
because I had helped those who were poor when they cried out for help,
and because I aided those who had no fathers, those who had no one else to help them.
Those who were suffering and about to die praised me,
and I caused widows to sing joyfully, because I helped them.
I always acted justly;
my actions were like a robe that I wore and like a turban that was wrapped around my head.
It was as though I myself saw for blind people
and walked for people who were lame.
I was like a father to the poor people,
and in the courts I defended those who were strangers to me.
I made wicked people stop oppressing others; it was like someone who breaks the teeth of wild animals
and forces them to drop their victims from their teeth.
At that time I thought, 'Surely I will live in peace until I am very old,
and I will die at home with my family.
I am like a tree whose roots reach down into the water
and whose branches become wet with dew each night.
People always honor me,
and I am always strong like a new bow.'
When I spoke, people waited to hear what I would say;
they remained silent until I advised them what they should do.
After I finished speaking, they did not say anymore;
it was as though my words fell on their ears like drops of rain.
They waited for me to speak as they wait for rain;
they liked what I said as farmers appreciate the final rain in the spring before the dry season.
When they were sad, I smiled at them to encourage them;
they became encouraged when they saw my cheerful face.
I was their leader, and I decided what things would be good for them to do;
I was among them like a king who is among his troops;
I was like someone who comforts others who are mourning."
"But now, men who are younger than I am make fun of me—
men whose fathers I greatly despised—
their fathers, whom I would not even have allowed to help my dogs guard my sheep.
They were men who were old and weak;
what could I gain from having these men work for me, even when they thought they were strong?
They were very poor and hungry,
so that they chewed on roots at night
in dry and desolate places.
They pulled up plants in the desert and ate them;
they warmed themselves by burning the roots of broom trees.
Everyone shouted at them, "Stop, thief!"
and drove them from their area.
They were forced to live in riverbeds,
in holes in the ground, and in the sides of cliffs.
In the bushes they howled like animals because they were hungry,
and they huddled together under thornbushes.
They were people without good sense,
whose names no one knows;
they were driven out from the land where they were born.
Now their children sing songs to make fun of me.
They tell jokes about me.
They are disgusted with me, and they stay away from me,
but when they see me, they are happy to spit in my face.
It seems as though God had cut my bowstring and caused me to be unable to defend myself; he has humbled me,
and my enemies have done to me whatever they wanted.
Gangs of these people attack me and force me to run away;
they prepare to destroy me.
They prevent me from escaping,
and there is no one to keep them from attacking me.
It is as though I were a city wall and they had broken through it,
as though they had come crashing down on me.
I am very terrified;
my dignity has been blown away by the wind,
and my prosperity has disappeared as clouds disappear.
Now I am about to die;
I suffer every day.
My bones ache during the nights,
and the pain that torments me never stops.
It is as though God had grabbed my clothes
and choked me by the collar of my coat.
He has thrown me into the mud;
I am not worth anything more than dust and ashes.
I cry out to you, God, but you do not answer me;
I stand up and pray, but you do not pay any attention.
You act very cruelly toward me;
with all of your power you cause me to suffer.
You allow the wind to lift me up and blow me away;
and you make a violent storm blow me around.
I know that you will cause me to die,
which is what happens to everyone who is alive.
When people experience disasters,
they sit on a pile of ruins and cry out for help;
they certainly cry out for help.
I myself wept for people who were experiencing troubles,
and I felt sorry for poor people.
However, when I expected good things to happen to me, evil things happened;
when I waited for light, I experienced darkness instead.
I am very distressed all the time;
I suffer every day.
I go about very discouraged;
I stand up and plead for people to help me.
My wailing is as sad as jackals and ostriches in the wilderness.
My skin has become dark and is peeling off,
and I have a fever which causes my body to feel as though it were burning up with a fever.
Previously, I played joyful music on my harp and with my flute,
but now I play only the sad music of those who mourn."
"I made to myself a solemn promise
that I would not look at a young woman and want to sleep with her.
If I did not do what I promised,
what would God who is in heaven give me?
Almighty God would certainly not give me any reward!
Previously I thought that surely it was unrighteous people who would experience calamities,
and that it was those who do what is wrong who would experience disasters.
God certainly sees everything that I do,
so why is he causing me to suffer?
It is as though he were counting every step that I take.
I solemnly declare that I have never acted wickedly
and have never tried to deceive people.
I request only that God judge me fairly;
if he does that, he will know that I am innocent.
If it were true that I had turned away from walking on the right paths,
or that I had seen wrong things to do and then did them,
or that my hands were stained because I had sinned,
then I hope that when I plant seeds, someone else will harvest the crops and eat them,
and that others will uproot the crops that I have planted.
If it is true that I have been attracted by some other man's wife,
or that I have hidden myself and waited outside the door to her house,
I hope another man will sleep with my own wife
and that she will sleep with him.
For me to do that would be a terrible sin,
and the judges would decide that I should be punished.
My adultery would produce in me a fire like the fire that burns people in hell,
and it would burn up everything that I own.
If it is true that I have ever refused to listen to one of my male or female servants
when they complained to me about something,
I hope that God would stand up and declare that he will punish me;
when he does that, what could I do?
If he asked me about what I have done, what would I answer?
God, who created me, certainly also created my servants;
surely he is the one who formed them and me in our mothers' wombs,
so we all should behave toward each other in the same way.
From the time I was young I have taken care of orphans;
So if it is true that I ate all my food myself and did not share some of it with orphans,
or that I refused to give poor people the things that they wanted,
or that I caused widows to live in despair, then you do to me whatever you must do to me.
If I had seen people die from cold because they had no clothes,
or that I had seen poor people who did not have clothes to keep them warm,
and they were not able to become warm from clothes made from the wool of my sheep
and they thanked me for it,
or if it is true that I threatened to strike any orphan
because I knew that the elders at the city gates would approve of me, then do to me whatever you must do to me.
For if those things were true about me, I hope that my shoulder blade would be torn out
and my arm be torn from my shoulder.
I always feared that God would cause me to experience a great disaster if I did any of those evil things,
and I would not have been able to endure the powerful things that he would do to punish me.
If it is true that I trusted in my gold,
or that I rejoiced because I had acquired many things
and had become very rich,
or that I looked at the sun when it was shining,
or that I looked at the beautiful moon,
and I had been tempted to worship them
by kissing my hand to honor them,
those things also would be sins for which the judges would say that I must be punished
because I would have been rejecting God by doing those things.
It is not true that I sinned by requesting God to curse people who hated me
and to cause them to die because I was angry with them.
It is not true that I was glad when they were ruined
or that I rejoiced when they experienced disasters. No!
No one can truthfully that I did not welcome travelers to stay in my house,
or that I did not open my doors to them, but that I forced them to sleep in the streets!
All the men who work for me certainly know that I have given food to anyone who needed it!
Some people try to hide their sins,
but I have never done that;
and I never remained silent and refused to go outside
because I was afraid of what people would say about me,
and that they would hate me.
I wish that there was someone who would hear what I am saying!
I solemnly declare that all that I have said is true.
I wish that those who oppose me would write down on a scroll the evil things that they say that I did.
If they did that, I would wear that scroll on my shoulder or on top of my head, in order that everyone could see it.
I would tell God everything that I have done,
and I would approach him like a ruler would, without being afraid.
If it is true that I have stolen land,
so that its furrows were like someone who shouted out to accuse me;
or that I have eaten the crops that grew in someone else's fields
without paying for those crops,
so that the farmers who grew those crops died from hunger;
then I wish that thorns would grow in my fields instead of wheat,
and that bad weeds would grow instead of barley!"
That is the end of what Job said to his three friends.
Then those three men stopped replying to Job because they could not convince Job that he had done anything wrong.

Then Elihu son of Barakel, a descendant of Buz, from the clan of Ram, became very angry at Job. He was angry because Job continued to claim that he was innocent, and that God had been wrong to punish him.
He was also angry with Job's three friends because they had declared that Job must have done many things that were wrong, but they could not convince him.
Now Elihu was younger than the others, so he waited until they had finished speaking before he replied to Job.
But when Elihu realized that the three men had no more to say to Job, he became angry.
This is what he said:
"I am young, and you all are much older than I am.
So I was timid, and I was afraid to tell you what I was thinking.
I said to myself, 'Let those who are much older speak
because older people should be able to say things that are wise.'
However, the Spirit of Almighty God is within people, and it is he who enables them to be wise.
Not all people become wise when they are old;
not all old people understand what is right.
That is why I say to you now, 'Listen to me,
and allow me to declare what I know.'
I waited for you all to speak;
I wanted to hear the wise things that you would say.
I waited while you thought carefully about what you should say.
I paid attention carefully,
but surprisingly, none of you was able to prove that what Job said was wrong.
So do not say to yourselves, 'We have discovered what is wise!'
It is God who must refute Job because you three have not been able to do that.
Job was replying to you, not to me,
so I will not reply to him by saying what you three have said.
I tell myself this: These three men are confused because they have nothing more to say to Job;
they have nothing more to say to him.
But because you do not speak, I certainly will not wait any longer;
you merely stand there and do not reply anymore.
So now I also will reply to Job
and tell him what I know.
I have plenty to say,
and my spirit forces me to say it.
My inner being is like a container of wine that is stretching more and more from the fermentation,
and it will soon burst.
I must speak in order that I can rest from trying to hold in my words;
I must say something to reply to you all.
I will speak fairly, not favoring any of you,
and I will not try to flatter anyone.
I really do not know how to flatter people;
if I did that, God would soon destroy me."
"Now, Job, listen carefully
to all that I am going to say.
I am ready to tell you what I think.
In my inner being I know that I am speaking honestly
and that I am speaking sincerely.
Almighty God has created me as well as you,
and with his breath he has caused me to live.
So answer what I say if you can;
think carefully what you will reply to me.
God considers that you and I are both the same;
he formed both of us from clay.
So you do not need to be afraid of me;
I will not speak against you harshly.
I have heard you speak,
and this is what you have said:
'I am innocent, and I have not committed any sins;
I am pure, and I have not done things that are wrong.
But God finds reasons to accuse me,
and he considers that I am his enemy.
It is as though he had put my feet in stocks,
and he watches everything that I do.'
However, what you have said is wrong,
and I will tell you what you have said that is wrong.
God is much greater than any human.
So, why are you arguing against God? He does not have to tell us why he does anything.
God does, indeed, speak to us in various ways,
but we do not pay any attention to what he says.
Sometimes he speaks to us at night in dreams and visions
when we are on our beds, heavily asleep.
He reveals things to us in those times;
he terrifies us by warning us about things.
He tells us those things in order that we may stop doing evil deeds
and to prevent us from becoming proud.
He does not want us to be destroyed;
he wants to prevent us from dying while we are still young.
God also corrects us by forcing us to lie on our beds, suffering much pain
and fever in our bones.
The result is that we do not desire any food,
not even very special food.
Our bodies become very thin so that we look like a skeleton,
and our bones stick out so others can count them.
We know that we will soon die
and go to the place where dead people are.
Yet sometimes an angel may come to one of us,
one of the thousands of angels who come to intervene between us and God,
to tell us what are the right things for us to do.
The angel is kind to us and says to God,
'Please release that person,
so that he does not descend to the place where dead people are!
Do that because I have found a way for you to keep him from dying!
Please let his body be strong again;
please allow him to be strong like he was when he was young!'
If that happens, that person will pray to God, and God will accept him;
he will enter God's presence joyfully,
and then he will tell others how God saved him from dying.
He will sing as he says to everyone,
'I sinned, and I did things that were not right,
but God did not punish me in the way that I deserved.
He has saved me from dying and going to the place where dead people are,
and I will continue to enjoy being alive.'
God does all these things for us many times;
he preserves us from dying and going to the place where the dead are,
in order that we can continue to enjoy being alive.
So Job, listen to me;
do not say anything more; just allow me to speak.
After I speak, if you have something more that you want to say to me,
say it, because I would like to find a way to declare that you are innocent.
However, if you have nothing more that you want to say, then just listen to me,
and I will teach you how to become wise."
Then Elihu continued by saying this:
"You men who think that you are very wise, listen to me;
listen to what I am saying, you men who say that you know so much.
When we hear people talk,
we think carefully about what they say to know what is good and what is bad,
as we taste food to know what is good to eat.
We must decide who is saying what is right,
and we must find out together for ourselves what is good.
Job has said, 'I am innocent,
but God has refused to judge me fairly.
Even though I have always done what is right,
he is lying about me.
Even though I have not done what is wrong,
he has caused me to suffer, and I will certainly die because of this.'
Is there any person like Job, who insults others as easily as people accept a drink of water?
He habitually associates with people who do what is evil
and spends time with wicked people.
He certainly does these things, because he has said, 'It is useless for people to try to please God.'
So, you men who claim that you understand everything, listen to me!
Almighty God would never consider doing anything that is wicked or wrong!
He pays back people for what they have done;
he gives them what they deserve for the way that they have conducted their lives.
Truly, Almighty God never does what is wicked;
he never calls wrongdoing right.
No one gave him the authority to rule everything on the earth;
no one put him in control of the whole world.
He has always had that authority.
If he ever thought only about himself and not about us also, and if he ever stopped making us live,
everyone would die immediately,
and their corpses would soon become soil again.
So, Job, if you say that you understand everything,
listen to what I am saying.
God could certainly never hate was is right and still rule the world.
So you really cannot criticize God, who is righteous and powerful, and you cannot say that what he has done is wrong, can you?
He tells some kings that they are worthless,
and he says to some officials that they are wicked.
He does not favor rulers more than he favors others;
he does not favor rich people more than poor people
because he created all of them.
They often die suddenly;
he strikes them at midnight and they die;
he gets rid of important people without the help of any humans.
He sees everything that people do;
when we walk, he watches every step that we take.
There is no gloom or darkness
in which wicked people can hide from God.
God does not need to set a time
when we will stand in front of him in order that he may judge us.
He already knows everything about us.
He destroys important people without needing to investigate what they have done,
and he appoints others to take their places.
Because he already knows what they have done,
he removes them at night and gets rid of them.
He strikes them because of the wicked things that they have done;
many people see him do it.
He strikes them down because they turned away from doing what he wanted them to do
and did not pay attention to any of his commands.
They mistreated poor people;
those poor people cried out to God for help,
and he heard them.
Yet even if God decides to do nothing to punish wicked people,
no one can criticize him.
God controls all nations and all people.
He does this so that those who rule over us may honor him,
so that our rulers do not oppress us.
Job, have you or anyone else ever said to God, 'I have certainly committed sin,
but I will not sin anymore;
so teach me what sins I have committed;
if I have done anything that is evil,
I will not do it anymore'?
Job, you object to what God has done to you,
but do you think that he will do what you want him to do?
It is you who must choose what you should say to God, not I;
tell me what you are thinking about this.
People who have good sense, those who are wise and who listen to what I say,
will say to me,
'Job is speaking ignorantly;
what he says is nonsense.'
To you friends of Job, I say this: I think that a court should thoroughly try Job,
because he answers us, his friends, as wicked men would answer.
To add to the other sins that he has committed, he is rebelling against God;
he shows us that he does not honor God;
he makes long speeches saying that God has punished him unjustly."
Then Elihu also said this:
"Job, do you really think that you have done nothing wrong?
You say, 'God knows that I am innocent,'
and you also say, 'What good have I received for not sinning?
What benefit have I received that I would not have had, even if I had sinned?'
Well, I will answer you,
and I will answer your three friends, too.
Job, look up at the sky;
look at the clouds that are high above you
and realize that God is far above everything, entirely out of your reach.
If you have sinned, that cannot harm God at all.
Even if you do wrong things many, many times, that certainly does not hurt him.
In the same way, if you are righteous, does that help God?
No, nothing you do can help him.
It is other people who can suffer because of the wicked things that you do;
In the same way, you might help others if you do good things for them.
People cry out because of the many things that others do to make them suffer;
they call for help because of the things that powerful people do to them.
But no one calls out to God
and says, 'Why does God, my creator, not help me?
He should enable me to sing joyful songs, instead of very sad songs, during the night.
He should be able to teach us more than he teaches the wild animals;
he should enable us to become wiser than all the birds are!'
People cry out for help,
but God does not answer them
because those who cry out are proud and evil people.
It is useless for them to cry out
because God, the Almighty One, does not pay any attention to what they say.
So when you complain that you cannot see God,
and you tell him that you are waiting for him to decide whether or not you have done wrong,
he will not listen to you, either!
Furthermore, you say that because he does not pay attention when people commit sins,
he does not become angry and punish them.
My friends, you see that Job has said things that are completely useless,
that he says many things without knowing what in the world he is talking about."
Elihu finished speaking by saying this:
"Job, be patient with me a little longer
because I have something else to teach you.
I have something else to say in order to prove that God does no wrong.
I will tell you what I have learned from many sources,
in order to show that God, my creator, is just.
I will not say anything to you that is false;
I, who am standing in front of you, am someone who understands things very well.
Really, God is very powerful, and he does not despise anyone,
and he understands everything.
He does not allow wicked people to remain alive—contrary to what you have claimed,
and he always acts justly toward those who are suffering.
He always watches over those who are righteous;
he makes them prosper, as if they were kings,
and he causes others to honor them forever.
However, if people who commit crimes are caught,
or if they suffer in prison for having done wrong,
then God shows them what they have done;
he shows them the sins that they have committed,
and he shows them that they have been arrogant.
He causes them to listen to what he is warning them,
and he commands them to turn away from doing what is evil.
If they listen to him and serve him,
they will prosper and be happy for all the years that they continue to live.
But if they do not listen to him,
they will die violently
because they understand nothing about God and what he wants them to do.
People who fail to honor God continue being angry,
and they do not cry out for help
even when God is punishing them.
They die while they are still young,
disgraced because of their immoral behavior.
God actually rescues people by causing them to suffer;
by afflicting them, he causes them to listen to what he is telling them.
Job, I think that God wants to bring you out of your troubles
and allow you to live without distress;
he wants your table to be full of very nice food.
However, now he is punishing you as he would punish the wicked;
God has judged you very rightly.
Do not let your anger give you an excuse to mock other people,
and do not let a large amount of money paid as a bribe
compel you to ruin your life.
If that happens, it certainly will not help you to cry out when you are distressed;
none of your strength will help you in that case.
Do not wish that it would be nighttime in order that you might mistreat others without anyone knowing it;
night is the time when even entire people groups are destroyed!
Be careful not to begin doing evil deeds,
because God has caused you to suffer to prevent you from doing evil.
Truly, people praise God because he is so powerful;
there is certainly no teacher who teaches what he teaches.
No one has told him what he should do,
and no one has said to him, 'You have done what is wrong!'
People have always sung songs to praise him,
so you also should never forget to praise him for what he has done.
All people have seen what he has done,
but we understand those things only a little.
How great God is! We are not able to know how great he is,
and we do not understand how old he is.
He draws water up from the earth and puts it in clouds
and causes it to become rain;
the rain pours down from the sky
and causes abundant showers to fall on everyone.
No one can understand how the clouds move across the sky
or how it thunders in the sky where God lives.
He causes lightning to flash all around him,
but he causes the oceans to remain dark.
By providing plenty of rain for everyone,
he gives them abundant food.
It is as though he were holding the lightning in his hands,
and then he commands it to strike where he wants it to.
When we hear his thunder, we know that there will be a storm,
and the cattle know it, too.
"My heart pounds when I think about that.
Listen, all of you, to the thunder,
which is like God's voice.
He sends thunder all across the sky,
and he sends lighting to the most distant places on the earth.
After the lightning flashes, we hear the thunder,
which is like God's powerful voice;
when he speaks, he does not keep back the lightning.
When God speaks, it causes us to fear him and admire him, as thunder does;
he does amazing things that we cannot understand.
He commands the snow to fall on the ground,
and often he makes it rain very hard.
When God does that, it prevents people from working,
in order that all people may know that he is the one who does these things.
When it rains, the animals go into their hiding places,
and they stay there until the rain stops.
The storms come from the place in the south where they start,
and the cold winds come from the north.
In the winter water freezes when he commands it,
and the lakes become ice.
God fills the clouds with moisture,
and lightning flashes everywhere from the clouds.
He guides the clouds and causes them to move back and forth
in order that they may accomplish all that he commands them to do all over the world.
Sometimes God sends rain to punish us, sometimes to water the land that he has made,
and sometimes because he wants to be very kind to us.
Job, listen to this;
stop and think about the wonderful things that God does.
Do you know how God commands the lightning to flash down from his clouds?
Do you know how God decides where to place the clouds in the sky?
Can you understand all the wonderful things that God does,
and how he knows everything and he knows them completely?
No, you just sweat there in your hot clothing
because even the clothes you wear become very hot.
Your clothing becomes hot because the heat builds up
when the wind comes from the south.
Can you stretch out the skies like God does and make them as hard as a metal mirror?
Job, you know so much! So tell us what we should say to God;
we do not know anything about how we should defend ourselves.
Should I ask someone to tell God that I want to speak to him?
No, because if I did that, he might destroy me.
You know that people cannot look directly at the sun
when it shines brightly in the sky after the wind has blown the clouds away;
likewise we certainly cannot look at the brightness of God.
God comes out of the north with a light that shines like gold;
his glory causes us to be afraid.
Almighty God has very great power,
and we do not know how to go near to him.
He always acts righteously,
and he will never mistreat us.
That is the reason that we have an awesome respect for him;
he does not pay attention to those who proudly, but wrongly, think that they are wise."
Then Yahweh spoke to Job from inside a powerful storm. He said to him,
"Who are you to bring confusion to what I plan to do?
You are speaking ignorantly!
I want to ask you some questions,
so act like a man and
get ready to answer my questions.
Where were you when I started to create the earth?
Since you know so much, tell me where you were at that time.
If it was not I who decided how large the earth would be, then who decided?
Do you know who stretched a line around the earth to measure it?
Since you think that you know so much, you should surely know that!
What supports the pillars on which the earth rests?
When the stars that shine early in the morning sang together,
and someone put in place the stone that causes the earth to stay in its place,
and all the angels shouted joyfully when they saw that happen,
who laid that cornerstone?
When the seas poured out from under the earth,
who prevented the water from flooding over the land?
It was I, not you, who caused clouds to come over the seas
and caused it to become very dark under those clouds.
I set limits for the seas,
and I put barriers so that the water would not come over the land.
I pointed to the shore and said to the water,
'I permit you to come up to here, but I do not permit you to come any farther.
Your powerful waves must stop here!'
Job, have you ever commanded the morning to begin?
Have you ever told the sun to start rising and begin a new day?
Have you ever told the dawn to spread out over the whole earth
with the result that wicked people run away from the light?
When it becomes light after the dawn,
the hills and the valleys become clear like a seal gives an image to the clay under it, or like the folds in a cloth.
When it becomes daylight, the wicked do not have the darkness that they like;
in the daylight they no longer are able to hurt anyone.
Job, have you traveled to the springs in the bottom of the ocean from which the water in the seas comes?
Have you investigated the very bottom of the oceans?
Has someone shown you the gates to the place where dead people are,
the gates to the place where it is very dark among those who are dead?
Do you know how big the earth is?
Tell me, if you know all these things!
Where is the road to the place where light comes from?
Can you tell me where darkness lives?
Can you take the light and the darkness to the places where they must do their work every day?
Do you know where the road is that goes back to their homes?
I am sure that you know these things
because you were born before the time when all things were created;
you must be very old!
Have you entered the place where I store the snow
and the place where I keep the hail?
I store the snow and the hail in order that I can use them when people are fighting on earth,
in times when they are fighting wars.
Where is the road to the place from which I cause the lightning to flash?
Where is the place from where the east wind begins to blow over all the earth?
Who created the channels in which the rain comes down from the sky?
Who makes the roads for the thunder in the air?
Who causes rain to fall in the desert,
in places where no one lives?
Who sends the rain that gives moisture to barren areas, areas where nothing has grown,
so that grass begins to grow again?
Does the rain have a father?
Does the dew also have a father?
From whose womb does ice come in the winter?
Who gives birth to the frost that comes down from the sky?
In the winter, the water freezes and becomes as hard as a rock,
and the surface of lakes becomes frozen.
Job, can you fasten the chains that hold the stars together in the cluster of the Pleiades stars?
Can you unfasten the cords of the stars in Orion?
Can you tell the stars and planets when they should shine?
Can you guide the stars in the groups of the Big Bear and the Little Bear?
Do you know the laws that the stars must obey?
Can you cause those same laws to rule everything here on the earth?
Can you shout commands up to the clouds and make rain pour down on you?
Can you cause flashes of lightning to come down and strike where you want them to strike?
Do those flashes say to you, 'Where do you want us to strike?'
Who enables the clouds to know when they should cause rain to fall?
Who is skilled enough to be able to count the clouds?
Who can tilt the containers of water in the sky to cause the rain to fall
so that the dry ground becomes hard
as the dry clods become wet and stick together?
When a lioness and her cubs crouch in their dens or hide in a thicket, waiting for some animal to pass by that they can kill,
can you find animals for the lioness to kill
so that she and her cubs can eat the meat and not be hungry anymore?
Who provides dead animals for the raven,
when its young are calling out to me for food,
when they are so weak because of their lack of food that they stagger around in their nests?
"Job, do you know at what time of the year the female mountain goats give birth?
Have you watched the wild deer while their calves were being born?
Do you know how many months pass from the time they become pregnant until their calves are born?
When they give birth, they crouch down,
and then their labor pangs are done.
The young calves grow up in the open fields,
and then they leave their mothers and do not return to them again.
Who allows the wild donkeys to go wherever they want away from the cities?
I am the one who has freed them and put them in the desert plain,
in places where grass does not grow.
They do not like the noise in the cities;
in the desert they do not have to listen to the shouts of those who forced them to work.
They go over the hills to find food;
there they search for grass to eat.
Will a wild ox agree to work for you?
Will it allow you to keep it penned up at night in the place where you put feed for your animals?
Can you fasten a rope on it
so that it will plow furrows in your fields, your fields in the valley?
Since it is very strong, can you for that reason trust it to work for you?
Can you go away after you tell it what work it should do and assume that it will do that work?
Can you rely on it to come back from the field
bringing your grain to the place where you thresh it?
Think also about the ostriches. They joyfully flap their wings,
but they have no love for their own young.
Ostriches lay their eggs on top of the ground and then walk away,
leaving the eggs to be warmed in the sand.
Ostriches never think about the possibility that some wild animal may step on the eggs and crush them.
Ostriches act cruelly toward their chicks;
they act as though the chicks belonged to some other ostrich.
They are not concerned if their chicks die,
that they may have laid their eggs for nothing.
That is because I did not allow ostriches to be wise.
I did not enable them to be intelligent.
However, when they get up and begin to run,
they scornfully laugh at horses with their riders
because the horses cannot run as fast as the ostriches!
Also, think about horses. Job, are you the one who made the horses to be strong?
Are you the one who put flowing manes on their necks?
Are you the one who enabled them to leap forward like locusts?
When they snort, they cause people to be afraid.
They paw the ground, rejoicing because they are very strong,
as they prepare to rush into battle.
It is as if they were laughing at the thought of being afraid. They are not afraid of anything!
They do not run away when the soldiers in the battle are fighting each other with swords.
The quivers containing the riders' arrows rattle against the horses' sides,
and the spears and javelins flash in the light of the sun.
The horses run very quickly, and they speedily cover the ground;
they rush into battle as soon as the trumpet is blown.
They neigh joyfully when they hear someone blowing the trumpet.
They can smell a battle even when they are far away,
and they understand what it means when the commanders shout their commands to their soldiers.
Think about big birds. Are you the one who enabled hawks to spread their wings
and fly to the south for the winter?
Do eagles fly high up into the cliffs to make their nests
because you commanded them to do that?
They live in holes in those cliffs.
They are safe in those high pointed rocks because no animals can reach them there.
As they watch carefully from there,
they see animals far away that they can kill.
After an eagle kills an animal,
the baby eagles drink the blood of that animal;
they gather wherever there are dead people lying on the ground."
Then Yahweh said to Job,
"Do you still want to argue with me, the Almighty One?
Since you criticize me, you should be able to answer my questions!"
Then Job replied to Yahweh,
"Now I realize that I am completely worthless. So how could I answer those questions?
I will put my hand over my mouth and not say anything.
I have already said more than I should have said,
so now I will say nothing more."
Then Yahweh again spoke to Job from inside a powerful storm. He said,
"I want to ask you some questions,
so act like a man and
get ready to answer my questions.
Are you going to accuse me and say that I am unjust?
Are you going to say that what I have done is wrong, in order that you can say that what you have done is right?
Do you have the same amount of power as I do?
Can your voice sound as loud as thunder, as mine can?
If you can do that, then put on the robes
that show that you are glorious and are greatly honored!
Show that you are very angry;
show that you have the right to humble people who are very proud!
Humble those proud people just by looking at them angrily!
Crush wicked people quickly!
Bury them in the ground!
Send them to the place where dead people are,
where they will not be able to get out!
If you do that, I will congratulate you
and say that truly you can save yourself by your own ability.
Think also about hippopotamuses.
I made you, and I made them also.
They eat grass, like oxen do.
Their legs are very strong,
and the muscles of their bellies are very powerful.
Their tails are stiff like the branches of a cedar tree.
The muscles of their thighs are close together.
Their thigh bones are like tubes made of bronze,
and the bones of their legs are like bars made of iron.
Hippopotamuses are among the strongest of the animals that I made,
and I, who created them, am the only one who can kill them.
On the hills grows food for them to eat
while many other wild animals play nearby.
They lie down in the water under the lotus plants;
they hide in tall reeds in the swamps.
The hippopotamuses find shade under the lotus plants,
and they are surrounded by willow trees growing in the streams.
They are not disturbed by raging, flooding rivers;
they are not even disturbed when rivers like the Jordan River rush over them.
No one can catch them with hooks
or by piercing their noses with the teeth of a trap!
"Think also about crocodiles.
Can you catch them with a fishhook
or fasten their jaws with a rope?
Can you put ropes through their noses to control them
or thrust hooks through their jaws?
Will they plead with you to act mercifully toward them
or use sweet talk in order that you will not harm them?
Will they make an agreement with you to work for you,
to be your slaves as long as they live?
Can you make them into pets like you do birds?
Can you put a leash around their necks so that your servant girls can play with them?
Will men who partner in selling fish try to sell them in the market?
Will they cut a crocodile up into pieces and sell the meat?
Can you pierce crocodiles through their hides by throwing fishing spears at them?
Can you pierce their heads with a harpoon?
If you grab one of them with your hands, it will give you a battle that you will never forget,
and you will never try to do it again!
It is useless to even hope to subdue them.
Anyone who tries to subdue one of them will fall to the ground out of fear.
No one dares to make a crocodile angry.
So, since I am much more powerful than they are, who would dare to cause me to be angry?
Also, everything on the earth is mine.
Therefore, no one is able to give anything to me and require me to pay money for it!
I will tell you about how strong crocodiles' legs are
and how strong their well formed bodies are.
Can anyone strip off their hides?
Can anyone pierce through their double layer of armor?
Can anyone pry open their jaws, which have terrible teeth in them?
They have rows of scales on their back
which are as hard as rock.
The scales are very close together;
not even air can get between them.
The scales are joined very closely to each other,
and they cannot be separated.
When crocodiles sneeze, the tiny drops of water that come out of their noses sparkle in the sunlight.
Their eyes are red like the rising sun.
It is as though sparks of fire poured out of their mouths.
Smoke pours out of their nostrils
as steam comes out of a pot that is put over a very, very hot fire.
Their breath can cause coals to blaze
and flames to shoot out from their mouths.
Their necks are very strong;
wherever they go, they make people very afraid.
The folds in their flesh are very close together
and are very hard.
They are fearless
because the inner parts of their bodies are as hard as a rock,
as hard as the lower millstone on which people grind grain.
When they rise up, they cause even very strong people to be terrified.
As a result, people fall back.
People cannot injure them with swords;
spears, arrows, or or other weapons with sharp points cannot injure them, either.
They certainly are not afraid of weapons made of straw or rotten wood,
but they are not even afraid of weapons made of iron or bronze!
Shooting arrows at them does not cause them to run away.
Hurling stones at them from a sling is like hurling bits of chaff at them.
They are not afraid of clubs anymore than they would be afraid of men throwing bits of straw at them,
and they laugh when they hear a spear coming at them.
Their bellies are covered with scales that are as sharp as broken pieces of pottery.
When they drag themselves through the mud,
their bellies tear up the ground like a plow.
They stir up the water and cause it to foam
as they churn through it.
As they go through the water, their wakes glisten.
People who see it would think that the foam had become white hair.
There are no creatures on earth that I have created as fearless as crocodiles.
They are the proudest of all the creatures;
they are like kings over all the other wild animals."
Then Job replied to Yahweh. He said,
"I know that you can do everything
and that no one can stop you from doing what you want to do.
You asked me, 'Who are you to bring confusion to what I plan to do? You are speaking ignorantly!'
It is true that I spoke about things that I did not understand,
things that are very amazing,
things about which I know nothing.
You said to me, 'Listen while I talk to you.
I want to ask you some questions,
so prepare yourself to answer them.'
I had heard about you previously by rumor,
but now it is as though I have seen you with my own eyes.
Therefore I am ashamed of what I said,
and I sit in dust and ashes to show that I am sorry for what I said."
After Yahweh said these things to Job, he said to Eliphaz, "I am angry with you and your two friends, Bildad and Zophar, because you did not say true things about me, as my servant Job did.

So now you must take to Job seven young bulls and seven rams and kill them and burn them on the altar as a sacrifice for yourselves. Then Job will pray for you, and I will do what he requests me to do. I will forgive you for speaking wrongly about me. I will not punish you, even though you deserve to be punished, because what you said about me was not right."
So Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar did what Yahweh commanded them to do, and Yahweh did what Job requested him to do for the three of them.
After Job prayed for his three friends, Yahweh healed him and caused him to become rich again. Yahweh gave him twice as many things as he had before.

Then all his brothers and sisters, and all the people who had known him before, came to his house, and they had a feast together. They consoled him because of all the troubles that Yahweh had allowed to happen to him. Each of them gave Job a piece of silver and a gold ring.

Then Yahweh blessed Job in the second half of his life more than he had blessed him in the first half of his life. He now acquired fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.
And he also had seven more sons and three more daughters.
He named the first daughter Jemimah, he named the second daughter Keziah, and he named the third daughter Keren Happuch.

In all of the land of Uz, there were no young women who were as beautiful as the daughters of Job, and Job declared that they would inherit some of his possessions, just as their brothers would inherit some.
After that, Job lived 140 more years. Before he died, he saw his great-great-grandchildren.
He was very old when he died.
